nodes.bodyText: 12c is not the only version, 11g works, maybe others too
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -23,47 +22,363 @@ connection properties as appropriate for your setup:
     connection-user=root
     connection-password=secret
 
-Multiple Oracle Servers
+Include catalog files on all of your nodes, this requires you to restart.
+
+By default, the Oracle connector uses connection pooling for performance
+improvement.
+
+The below configuration shows the typical default values. To update them, change
+the properties in the catalog configuration file:
+
+.. code-block:: properties
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.max-size=30
+    oracle.connection-pool.min-size=1
+    oracle.connection-pool.inactive-timeout=20m
+
+To disable connection pooling, update properties to include:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.enabled=false
+
+Multiple Oracle servers
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
 
-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle plugin as a separate catalog.
+
+To add another Oracle catalog, create a new properties file. For example, if
+you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto creates a catalog named
+sales.
 
 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.
-You can see the available Oracle databases by running ``SHOW SCHEMAS``::
+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle server. Use the below
+queries to test your setup.
+
+If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use that catalog
+name instead of ``oracle``.
+
+.. note::
+    The user configuration, in the connection properties file, determines your
+    privileges in these schemas. If the user doesn't have access to these
+    tables, you can't access them either.
+
+
+Run ``SHOW SCHEMAS`` to see the available Oracle databases::
 
     SHOW SCHEMAS FROM oracle;
 
-If you have a Oracle database named ``web``, you can view the tables
-in this database by running ``SHOW TABLES``::
+If you have an Oracle database named ``web``, run ``SHOW TABLES`` to see the
+tables it owns::
 
     SHOW TABLES FROM oracle.web;
 
-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::
+To see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web``
+database run either of the following::
 
     DESCRIBE oracle.web.clicks;
     SHOW COLUMNS FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-Finally, you can access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database::
+To access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database run::
 
     SELECT * FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle and Presto support types that the other doesn't, the following tables
+show their type mapping:
+
+.. list-table:: Type mapping properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``               
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.
+      - ``HALF_UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding up is used
+      - ``UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+      - ``DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+
+    - ``UNNECESSARY``
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   Oracle connectors can't write Presto types that aren't listed in the table.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Presto type
+    - Oracle database type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``TINYINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+ - No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+   ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+ - Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+ - Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+ - Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+   38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+   ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+
+If a column meets any of these conditions, it shows an error:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration) any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+If ``s`` is negative, ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to ``DECIMAL(p + s, 0)``.
+
+For Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision and scale), you can change
+``oracle.number.default-scale=s`` and map the column to ``DECIMAL(38, s)``.
+
+.. _datetime mapping:
+
+Mapping datetime types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.
+
+Oracle ``DATE`` values may store hours, minutes, and seconds, mapped
+to Presto ``TIMESTAMP``.
+
+.. warning::
+
+  Due to date and time differences in the libraries used by Presto and the
+  Oracle JDBC driver, attempting to insert or select a datetime value earlier
+  than ``1582-10-15`` results in an incorrect date inserted.
+
+.. _character mapping:
+
+Mapping character types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto's ``VARCHAR(n)`` maps to ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than
+4000. A larger or unbounded ``VARCHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Presto's ``CHAR(n)`` maps to ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than 2000.
+A larger ``CHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Using ``CREATE TABLE AS`` to create an ``NCLOB`` column from a ``CHAR`` value
+removes the trailing spaces from the initial values for the column. Inserting
+``CHAR`` values into existing ``NCLOB`` columns keeps the trailing spaces. For
+example::
+
+    presto> CREATE TABLE vals AS SELECT CAST('A' as CHAR(2001)) col;
+    presto> INSERT INTO vals (col) VALUES (CAST('BB' as CHAR(2001)));
+    presto> SELECT LENGTH(col) FROM vals;
+    2001
+    1
+
+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size
+fails. This is also true for the equivalent ``VARCHAR`` types.
+
+.. note:: 
+
+    This behaviors above may change in a future version.
+
+
+Synonyms
+--------
+
+Based on performance reasons, Presto disables support for Oracle ``SYNONYM``. To
+include ``SYNONYM``, add the following: 
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.synonyms.enabled=true
+
+Pushdown
+--------
+
+The connector supports :doc:`pushdown </optimizer/pushdown>` for optimized query
+processing.
 
 Limitations
 -----------
 
-The following SQL statements are not yet supported:
+Presto supports connecting to Oracle Database 12c. The following SQL statements

@@ -23,47 +22,363 @@ connection properties as appropriate for your setup:
     connection-user=root
     connection-password=secret
 
-Multiple Oracle Servers
+Include catalog files on all of your nodes, this requires you to restart.
+
+By default, the Oracle connector uses connection pooling for performance
+improvement.
+
+The below configuration shows the typical default values. To update them, change
+the properties in the catalog configuration file:
+
+.. code-block:: properties
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.max-size=30
+    oracle.connection-pool.min-size=1
+    oracle.connection-pool.inactive-timeout=20m
+
+To disable connection pooling, update properties to include:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.enabled=false
+
+Multiple Oracle servers
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
 
-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle plugin as a separate catalog.

nodes.bodyText: Use database - not server. Database comes from Oracle nomenclature, and it is about logical data structure in Oracle. It has nothing to do with physical Oracle servers.

+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle and Presto support types that the other doesn't, the following tables
+show their type mapping:
+
+.. list-table:: Type mapping properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``               
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.

nodes.bodyText:
The problem that it is hard to follow (at least to me) that it says about different possible outcomes, depending on value of configuration property unsupported-type.handling-strategy.
Also I have just noticed that each option is marked with "(default configuration)" :).
Also it should be unsupported-type.handling (without -strategy); The version with -strategy would work too, but it is legacy and will be removed eventually.
I would expect something like:
You can specify Presto behaviour for situation when type not listed above is used in Oracle table by setting `unsupported-type.handling-strategy` configuration property.

If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``FAIL``  querying table with unsupported table will fail.

If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``IGNORE`` (default configuration) columns with unsupported types will not be exposed in Presto.

If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` column will be exposed as unbounded VARCHAR

Of course please make it more English :)

+    oracle.connection-pool.max-size=30
+    oracle.connection-pool.min-size=1
+    oracle.connection-pool.inactive-timeout=20m
+
+To disable connection pooling, update properties to include:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.enabled=false
+
+Multiple Oracle servers
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
 
-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle plugin as a separate catalog.
+
+To add another Oracle catalog, create a new properties file. For example, if
+you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto creates a catalog named
+sales.
 
 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.
-You can see the available Oracle databases by running ``SHOW SCHEMAS``::
+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle server. Use the below
+queries to test your setup.
+
+If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use that catalog
+name instead of ``oracle``.
+
+.. note::
+    The user configuration, in the connection properties file, determines your
+    privileges in these schemas. If the user doesn't have access to these
+    tables, you can't access them either.
+
+
+Run ``SHOW SCHEMAS`` to see the available Oracle databases::
 
     SHOW SCHEMAS FROM oracle;
 
-If you have a Oracle database named ``web``, you can view the tables
-in this database by running ``SHOW TABLES``::
+If you have an Oracle database named ``web``, run ``SHOW TABLES`` to see the
+tables it owns::
 
     SHOW TABLES FROM oracle.web;
 
-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::
+To see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web``
+database run either of the following::
 
     DESCRIBE oracle.web.clicks;
     SHOW COLUMNS FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-Finally, you can access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database::
+To access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database run::
 
     SELECT * FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle and Presto support types that the other doesn't, the following tables
+show their type mapping:
+
+.. list-table:: Type mapping properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``               
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.
+      - ``HALF_UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding up is used
+      - ``UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+      - ``DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+
+    - ``UNNECESSARY``
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   Oracle connectors can't write Presto types that aren't listed in the table.

+conditions:

+   ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+ - Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+ - Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+ - Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+   38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+   ``UNNECESSARY``.

+If a column meets any of these conditions, it shows an error:

-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle plugin as a separate catalog.
+
+To add another Oracle catalog, create a new properties file. For example, if
+you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto creates a catalog named
+sales.
 
 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.
-You can see the available Oracle databases by running ``SHOW SCHEMAS``::
+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle server. Use the below
+queries to test your setup.
+
+If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use that catalog
+name instead of ``oracle``.
+
+.. note::
+    The user configuration, in the connection properties file, determines your
+    privileges in these schemas. If the user doesn't have access to these
+    tables, you can't access them either.
+
+
+Run ``SHOW SCHEMAS`` to see the available Oracle databases::
 
     SHOW SCHEMAS FROM oracle;
 
-If you have a Oracle database named ``web``, you can view the tables
-in this database by running ``SHOW TABLES``::
+If you have an Oracle database named ``web``, run ``SHOW TABLES`` to see the
+tables it owns::
 
     SHOW TABLES FROM oracle.web;
 
-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::
+To see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web``
+database run either of the following::
 
     DESCRIBE oracle.web.clicks;
     SHOW COLUMNS FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-Finally, you can access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database::
+To access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database run::
 
     SELECT * FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle and Presto support types that the other doesn't, the following tables
+show their type mapping:
+
+.. list-table:: Type mapping properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``               
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.
+      - ``HALF_UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding up is used
+      - ``UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+      - ``DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+
+    - ``UNNECESSARY``
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   Oracle connectors can't write Presto types that aren't listed in the table.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Presto type
+    - Oracle database type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``TINYINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+ - No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+   ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+ - Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+ - Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+ - Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+   38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+   ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+
+If a column meets any of these conditions, it shows an error:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration) any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+If ``s`` is negative, ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to ``DECIMAL(p + s, 0)``.
+
+For Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision and scale), you can change
+``oracle.number.default-scale=s`` and map the column to ``DECIMAL(38, s)``.
+
+.. _datetime mapping:
+
+Mapping datetime types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.

nodes.bodyText:
"Connectors let Presto join data provided by different databases,
like Oracle and Hive, or different Oracle database instances." is accurate though I am not sure if needed at all.
Technically one can put such sentence in the intro for any connector documentation.
With that said I do not consider myself proficient documentation writer so I leave the call to you.

@@ -23,47 +20,362 @@ connection properties as appropriate for your setup:
     connection-user=root
     connection-password=secret
 
-Multiple Oracle Servers
+The below configuration shows the typical default values. To update them, change
+the properties in the catalog configuration file:
+
+.. code-block:: properties
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.max-size=30
+    oracle.connection-pool.min-size=1
+    oracle.connection-pool.inactive-timeout=20m
+
+By default, the Oracle connector uses connection pooling for performance
+improvement. To disable connection pooling, update properties to include:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.enabled=false
+
+.. note::
+
+    Include catalog files on all of your nodes, this requires you to restart.
+
+Multiple Oracle servers
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
 
-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle connector as a separate catalog.
+
+To add another Oracle catalog, create a new properties file. For example, if
+you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto creates a catalog named
+sales.
 
 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.
-You can see the available Oracle databases by running ``SHOW SCHEMAS``::
+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle database. Use the below
+queries to test your setup.
+
+If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use that catalog
+name instead of ``oracle``.
+
+.. note::
+    The user configuration, in the connection properties file, determines your
+    privileges in these schemas. If the Oracle user doesn't have access to a
+    table, you can't access it through Presto either.
+
+Run ``SHOW SCHEMAS`` to see the available Oracle databases::
 
     SHOW SCHEMAS FROM oracle;
 
-If you have a Oracle database named ``web``, you can view the tables
-in this database by running ``SHOW TABLES``::
+If you have an Oracle database named ``web``, run ``SHOW TABLES`` to see the
+tables it contains::
 
     SHOW TABLES FROM oracle.web;
 
-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::
+To see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web``
+database run either of the following::
 
     DESCRIBE oracle.web.clicks;
     SHOW COLUMNS FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-Finally, you can access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database::
+To access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database run::
 
     SELECT * FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle supports types that Presto doesn't and Presto supports types that Oracle
+doesn't. The following sections explain their type mapping.
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   For types not listed in the table below, Presto can't perform the ``CREATE
+   TABLE`` and ``AS SELECT``operations to insert info into existing
+   tables that use ``Oracle to Presto`` type mapping.

+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   For types not listed in the table below, Presto can't perform the ``CREATE
+   TABLE`` and ``AS SELECT``operations to insert info into existing
+   tables that use ``Oracle to Presto`` type mapping.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Presto type
+    - Oracle database type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``TINYINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+ - No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+   ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+ - Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+ - Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+ - Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+   38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+   ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+
+If a column meets any of the conditions:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration) any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.

+    privileges in these schemas. If the Oracle user doesn't have access to a

-using either of the following::

-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle supports types that Presto doesn't and Presto supports types that Oracle
+doesn't. The following sections explain their type mapping.
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   For types not listed in the table below, Presto can't perform the ``CREATE
+   TABLE`` and ``AS SELECT``operations to insert info into existing
+   tables that use ``Oracle to Presto`` type mapping.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Presto type
+    - Oracle database type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``TINYINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+ - No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+   ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+ - Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+ - Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+ - Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+   38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+   ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+
+If a column meets any of the conditions:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration) any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+If ``s`` is negative, ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to ``DECIMAL(p + s, 0)``.
+
+For Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision and scale), you can change
+``oracle.number.default-scale=s`` and map the column to ``DECIMAL(38, s)``.
+
+.. _datetime mapping:
+
+Mapping datetime types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.
+
+Oracle ``DATE`` type may store hours, minutes, and seconds, so it is mapped
+to Presto ``TIMESTAMP``.
+
+.. warning::
+
+  Due to date and time differences in the libraries used by Presto and the
+  Oracle JDBC driver, attempting to insert or select a datetime value earlier
+  than ``1582-10-15`` results in an incorrect date inserted.
+
+.. _character mapping:
+
+Mapping character types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto's ``VARCHAR(n)`` maps to ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than
+4000. A larger or unbounded ``VARCHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Presto's ``CHAR(n)`` maps to ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than 2000.
+A larger ``CHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Using ``CREATE TABLE AS`` to create an ``NCLOB`` column from a ``CHAR`` value
+removes the trailing spaces from the initial values for the column. Inserting
+``CHAR`` values into existing ``NCLOB`` columns keeps the trailing spaces. For
+example::
+
+    presto> CREATE TABLE vals AS SELECT CAST('A' as CHAR(2001)) col;
+    presto> INSERT INTO vals (col) VALUES (CAST('BB' as CHAR(2001)));
+    presto> SELECT LENGTH(col) FROM vals;
+    2001
+    1
+
+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size
+fails. This is also true for the equivalent ``VARCHAR`` types.
+
+
+Type mapping configuration properties
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+.. list-table:: Type Mapping Properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.

+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.
+
+Oracle ``DATE`` type may store hours, minutes, and seconds, so it is mapped
+to Presto ``TIMESTAMP``.
+
+.. warning::
+
+  Due to date and time differences in the libraries used by Presto and the
+  Oracle JDBC driver, attempting to insert or select a datetime value earlier
+  than ``1582-10-15`` results in an incorrect date inserted.
+
+.. _character mapping:
+
+Mapping character types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto's ``VARCHAR(n)`` maps to ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than
+4000. A larger or unbounded ``VARCHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Presto's ``CHAR(n)`` maps to ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than 2000.
+A larger ``CHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Using ``CREATE TABLE AS`` to create an ``NCLOB`` column from a ``CHAR`` value
+removes the trailing spaces from the initial values for the column. Inserting
+``CHAR`` values into existing ``NCLOB`` columns keeps the trailing spaces. For
+example::
+
+    presto> CREATE TABLE vals AS SELECT CAST('A' as CHAR(2001)) col;
+    presto> INSERT INTO vals (col) VALUES (CAST('BB' as CHAR(2001)));
+    presto> SELECT LENGTH(col) FROM vals;
+    2001
+    1
+
+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size
+fails. This is also true for the equivalent ``VARCHAR`` types.
+
+
+Type mapping configuration properties
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+.. list-table:: Type Mapping Properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        in which case rounding towards the nearest neighbor is
+        performed.

     connection-user=root
     connection-password=secret
 
-Multiple Oracle Servers
+By default, the Oracle connector uses connection pooling for performance
+improvement. The below configuration shows the typical default values. To update
+them, change the properties in the catalog configuration file:
+
+.. code-block:: properties
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.max-size=30
+    oracle.connection-pool.min-size=1
+    oracle.connection-pool.inactive-timeout=20m
+
+To disable connection pooling, update properties to include:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.connection-pool.enabled=false
+
+.. note::
+
+    Include catalog files on all of your nodes, this requires you to restart.
+
+Multiple Oracle servers
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
 
-You can have as many catalogs as you need, so if you have additional
-Oracle servers, simply add another properties file to ``etc/catalog``
-with a different name (making sure it ends in ``.properties``). For
-example, if you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto
-will create a catalog named ``sales`` using the configured connector.
+If you want to connect to multiple Oracle servers, configure another instance of
+the Oracle connector as a separate catalog.
+
+To add another Oracle catalog, create a new properties file. For example, if
+you name the property file ``sales.properties``, Presto creates a catalog named
+sales.
 
 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.
-You can see the available Oracle databases by running ``SHOW SCHEMAS``::
+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle database. Use the below
+queries to test your setup.
+
+If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use that catalog
+name instead of ``oracle``.
+
+.. note::
+    The user configuration, in the connection properties file, determines your
+    privileges in these schemas. If the Oracle user doesn't have access to a
+    table, you can't access it through Presto either.
+
+Run ``SHOW SCHEMAS`` to see the available Oracle databases::
 
     SHOW SCHEMAS FROM oracle;
 
-If you have a Oracle database named ``web``, you can view the tables
-in this database by running ``SHOW TABLES``::
+If you have an Oracle database named ``web``, run ``SHOW TABLES`` to see the
+tables it contains::
 
     SHOW TABLES FROM oracle.web;
 
-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::
+To see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web``
+database run either of the following::
 
     DESCRIBE oracle.web.clicks;
     SHOW COLUMNS FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-Finally, you can access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database::
+To access the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database run::
 
     SELECT * FROM oracle.web.clicks;
 
-If you used a different name for your catalog properties file, use
-that catalog name instead of ``oracle`` in the above examples.
+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle supports types that Presto doesn't and Presto supports types that Oracle
+doesn't. The following sections explain their type mapping.
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+If an Oracle table contains a type that's not listed in the above table, an
+error shows:
+
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``FAIL``
+   (default configuration), any queries on the table fail.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``IGNORE``
+   (default configuration), Presto no longer accesses the column.
+ - An ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy`` equals ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``
+   (default configuration), a column value converts to an unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::
+   For types not listed in the table below, Presto can't perform the ``CREATE
+   TABLE <table> AS SELECT`` operations. When data is inserted into existing
+   tables ``Oracle to Presto`` type mapping is used.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Presto type
+    - Oracle database type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``TINYINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these

+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+- No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+  ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+- Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+- Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+- Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+  38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+  ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+   
+If ``s`` is negative, ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to ``DECIMAL(p + s, 0)``.
+
+For Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision and scale), you can change
+``oracle.number.default-scale=s`` and map the column to ``DECIMAL(38, s)``.
+
+.. _datetime mapping:
+
+Mapping datetime types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.
+
+Oracle ``DATE`` type may store hours, minutes, and seconds, so it is mapped
+to Presto ``TIMESTAMP``.
+
+.. warning::
+
+  Due to date and time differences in the libraries used by Presto and the
+  Oracle JDBC driver, attempting to insert or select a datetime value earlier
+  than ``1582-10-15`` results in an incorrect date inserted.
+
+.. _character mapping:
+
+Mapping character types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto's ``VARCHAR(n)`` maps to ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than
+4000. A larger or unbounded ``VARCHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Presto's ``CHAR(n)`` maps to ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than 2000.
+A larger ``CHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Using ``CREATE TABLE AS`` to create an ``NCLOB`` column from a ``CHAR`` value
+removes the trailing spaces from the initial values for the column. Inserting
+``CHAR`` values into existing ``NCLOB`` columns keeps the trailing spaces. For
+example::
+
+    presto> CREATE TABLE vals AS SELECT CAST('A' as CHAR(2001)) col;
+    presto> INSERT INTO vals (col) VALUES (CAST('BB' as CHAR(2001)));
+    presto> SELECT LENGTH(col) FROM vals;
+    2001
+    1
+
+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size
+fails. This is also true for the equivalent ``VARCHAR`` types.
+
+
+Type mapping configuration properties
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+.. list-table:: Type Mapping Properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are equidistant,
+        in which case rounding towards the even neighbor is
+        performed.
+      - ``HALF_UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding up is used
+      - ``UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+      - ``DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+
+    - ``UNNECESSARY``
+
+Synonyms
+--------
+
+Based on performance reasons, Presto disables support for Oracle ``SYNONYM``. To
+include ``SYNONYM``, add the following: 
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.synonyms.enabled=true
+
+Pushdown
+--------
+
+The connector supports :doc:`pushdown </optimizer/pushdown>` for optimized query
+processing.
 
 Limitations
 -----------

+The following SQL statements aren't supported:

nodes.bodyText:
I was using contractions based on the Google Style Guide: https://developers.google.com/style/contractions

Negation contractions
In particular, it's fine to use -n't contractions, such as isn't, don't, and can't.


One reason that such contractions are useful is that it's sometimes easy for a reader to miss the word not, whereas it's harder to misread don't as do.

I can change it back, if that's not a part of the guidance that we want to follow.

+    - ``TIMESTAMP``

+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`

+Use the default configureation property, ``unsupported-type.handling``, to specify
+Presto behavior if an Oracle table uses a type not listed in the above table.

+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+An Oracle ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to Presto's ``DECIMAL(p, s)`` except in these
+conditions:
+
+- No precision is specified for the column (example: ``NUMBER`` or
+  ``NUMBER(*)``), unless ``oracle.number.default-scale`` is set. 
+- Scale (``s`` ) is greater than precision. 
+- Precision (``p`` ) is greater than 38. 
+- Scale is negative and the difference between ``p`` and ``s`` is greater than
+  38, unless ``oracle.number.rounding-mode`` is set to a different value than
+  ``UNNECESSARY``. 
+   
+If ``s`` is negative, ``NUMBER(p, s)`` maps to ``DECIMAL(p + s, 0)``.
+
+For Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision and scale), you can change
+``oracle.number.default-scale=s`` and map the column to ``DECIMAL(38, s)``.
+
+.. _datetime mapping:
+
+Mapping datetime types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Selecting a timestamp with fractional second precision (``p``) greater than 3
+truncates the fractional seconds to three digits instead of rounding it.
+
+Oracle ``DATE`` type may store hours, minutes, and seconds, so it is mapped
+to Presto ``TIMESTAMP``.
+
+.. warning::
+
+  Due to date and time differences in the libraries used by Presto and the
+  Oracle JDBC driver, attempting to insert or select a datetime value earlier
+  than ``1582-10-15`` results in an incorrect date inserted.
+
+.. _character mapping:
+
+Mapping character types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto's ``VARCHAR(n)`` maps to ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than
+4000. A larger or unbounded ``VARCHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Presto's ``CHAR(n)`` maps to ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` if ``n`` is no greater than 2000.
+A larger ``CHAR`` maps to ``NCLOB``.
+
+Using ``CREATE TABLE AS`` to create an ``NCLOB`` column from a ``CHAR`` value
+removes the trailing spaces from the initial values for the column. Inserting
+``CHAR`` values into existing ``NCLOB`` columns keeps the trailing spaces. For
+example::
+
+    presto> CREATE TABLE vals AS SELECT CAST('A' as CHAR(2001)) col;
+    presto> INSERT INTO vals (col) VALUES (CAST('BB' as CHAR(2001)));
+    presto> SELECT LENGTH(col) FROM vals;
+    2001
+    1
+
+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size
+fails. This is also true for the equivalent ``VARCHAR`` types.
+
+
+Type mapping configuration properties
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+.. list-table:: Type Mapping Properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Configuration property name
+    - Session property name
+    - Description
+    - Default
+  * - ``unsupported-type.handling-strategy``
+    - ``unsupported_type_handling_strategy``
+    - Configures how unsupported column data types are handled:
+
+      - ``IGNORE`` - column is not accessible.
+      - ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` - column is converted to unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+    - ``IGNORE``
+  * - ``oracle.number.default-scale``
+    - ``number_default_scale``               
+    - Default Presto ``DECIMAL`` scale for Oracle ``NUMBER`` (without precision 
+      and scale) date type. When not set then such column is treated as not 
+      supported.
+    - not set
+  * - ``oracle.number.rounding-mode``
+    - ``number_rounding_mode``
+    - Rounding mode for the Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type. This is useful when 
+      Oracle ``NUMBER`` data type specifies higher scale than is supported in 
+      Presto. Possible values are:
+
+      - ``UNNECESSARY`` - Rounding mode to assert that the 
+        requested operation has an exact result, 
+        hence no rounding is necessary.
+      - ``CEILING`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        positive infinity.
+      - ``FLOOR`` - Rounding mode to round towards negative
+        infinity.
+      - ``HALF_DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding down is used.
+      - ``HALF_EVEN`` - Rounding mode to round towards the
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are equidistant,
+        in which case rounding towards the even neighbor is
+        performed.
+      - ``HALF_UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards
+        ``nearest neighbor`` unless both neighbors are
+        equidistant, in which case rounding up is used
+      - ``UP`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+      - ``DOWN`` - Rounding mode to round towards zero.
+
+    - ``UNNECESSARY``
+
+Synonyms
+--------
+
+Based on performance reasons, Presto disables support for Oracle ``SYNONYM``. To
+include ``SYNONYM``, add the following: 
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    oracle.synonyms.enabled=true
+
+Pushdown
+--------
+
+The connector supports :doc:`pushdown </optimizer/pushdown>` for optimized query
+processing.

+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle supports types that Presto doesn't and Presto supports types that Oracle
+doesn't. The following sections explain their type mapping.
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1

+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+Use the default configureation property, ``unsupported-type.handling``, to specify
+Presto behavior if an Oracle table uses a type not listed in the above table.
+For example:
+
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``FAIL``, then the
+  querying of unsupported tables fail.
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``IGNORE``, 
+  then you can't see the unsupported types in Presto.
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR`` 
+  column is exposed as unbounded ``VARCHAR``.
+
+Presto to Oracle type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports creating tables with the following types in an Oracle database.
+The table shows the mappings from Presto to Oracle data types:
+
+.. note::

+   TABLE <table> AS SELECT`` operations. When data is inserted into existing
+   tables ``Oracle to Presto`` type mapping is used.
+
+.. list-table:: Presto to Oracle Type Mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1

+    - Notes

+    - ``NUMBER(3)``
+    -
+  * - ``SMALLINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(5)``
+    -
+  * - ``INTEGER``
+    - ``NUMBER(10)``
+    -
+  * - ``BIGINT``
+    - ``NUMBER(19)``
+    -
+  * - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    -
+  * - ``REAL``
+    - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    -
+  * - ``DOUBLE``
+    - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR``
+    - ``NCLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n CHAR)`` or ``NCLOB``
+    - See :ref:`character mapping`
+  * - ``VARBINARY``
+    - ``BLOB``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``DATE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3)``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP(3) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+.. _number mapping:
+
+Mapping numeric types
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

+Attempting to write a ``CHAR`` that doesn't fit in the column's actual size

+Type mapping configuration properties
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+.. list-table:: Type Mapping Properties
+  :widths: 20, 20, 50, 10

+
+  * - Configuration property name

 Querying Oracle
 ---------------
 
-The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle *database*.

+The Oracle connector provides a schema for every Oracle database. Use the below

-using either of the following::

+Mapping data types between Presto and Oracle
+--------------------------------------------
+
+Oracle supports types that Presto doesn't and Presto supports types that Oracle
+doesn't. The following sections explain their type mapping.
+
+Oracle to Presto type mapping
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+Presto supports selecting Oracle database types. This table shows the Oracle to
+Presto data type mapping:
+
+
+.. list-table:: Oracle to Presto type mapping
+  :widths: 20, 20, 60
+  :header-rows: 1
+
+  * - Oracle database type
+    - Presto type
+    - Notes
+  * - ``NUMBER(p, s)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, s)``
+    -  See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``NUMBER(p)``
+    - ``DECIMAL(p, 0)``
+    - See :ref:`number mapping`
+  * - ``FLOAT[(p)]``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_FLOAT``
+    - ``REAL``
+    -
+  * - ``BINARY_DOUBLE``
+    - ``DOUBLE``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n CHAR)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``VARCHAR2(n BYTE)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NVARCHAR2(n)``
+    - ``VARCHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``NCHAR(n)``
+    - ``CHAR(n)``
+    -
+  * - ``CLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``NCLOB``
+    - ``VARCHAR``
+    -
+  * - ``RAW(n)``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``BLOB``
+    - ``VARBINARY``
+    -
+  * - ``DATE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p)``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+  * - ``TIMESTAMP(p) WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - ``TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE``
+    - See :ref:`datetime mapping`
+
+Use the default configureation property, ``unsupported-type.handling``, to specify

nodes.bodyText:
This sentence was suggested by @losipiuk .. however I am not sure this actually true. At least all other connector docs suggest that the Presto to Oracle mapping is used for ALL write operations .. and not just for CTAS ...
Can you clarify if the Oracle connector is just different or if all other docs are wrong or whatever is technically correct @losipiuk @findepi and @electrum

+For example:
+
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``FAIL``, then the
+  querying of an unsupported table fails.
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``IGNORE``, 
+  then you can't see the unsupported types in Presto.
+- If ``unsupported-type.handling`` is set to ``CONVERT_TO_VARCHAR``, 
+  then the column is exposed as unbounded ``VARCHAR``.

nodes.bodyText:
The "Presto to " mapping is used only in CTAS flow, when the external table does not yet exist, and we need to build the a schema for it based on Presto types of data used in CTAS statement.
For query operations as well as INSERT operations the " to Presto" mapping is used. We already have columns in external database and we map types of those columns to Presto types.
This is not Oracle specific, but true for all connectors based on presto-base-jdbc.
Still I am not at all defending the wording I suggested. It is highly probable that one can phrase it much better :)
Hera are the code pointers:

CTAS: https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/fd66bb72ddb9cfc311511900b1454cef385f172d/presto-base-jdbc/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/jdbc/JdbcPageSink.java#L74
INSERT: https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/fd66bb72ddb9cfc311511900b1454cef385f172d/presto-base-jdbc/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/jdbc/JdbcPageSink.java#L89

-You can see a list of the columns in the ``clicks`` table in the ``web`` database
-using either of the following::

So looking at the code I conclude that this is true for all connectors that use the base-jdbc stuff .. so including mysql, postgresql, oracle, sqlserver and maybe others.
At this stage I suggest we leave the wording as it is in this PR and create another PR that clarifies this and corrects the docs for all affected connectors. Do you agree with this approach @losipiuk  and @electrum  .. if yes .. can we get this PR merged.

+  querying of an unsupported table fails.
